sentence: T he holiday shopping season is usually when the retail industry finds out how much of a thumping Amazon.com gave to traditional, brick-and-mortar retail chains.
For many investors of the e-commerce behemoth, though, the real excitement surroundingAmazon ( AMZN ) is not its core online retailing, but its Web services business.

Known as Amazon Web Services, or AWS, it contributes only a small percentage of Amazon.com's overall revenue -- slightly more than 8% last quarter -- it's a big reason the company's stock price has more than doubled this year and has been trading at record highs, analysts say.
"Amazon has seen accelerated growth over the last few quarters as they've benefited from Web services and computer services functionality," said Fred Moran, analyst at Burke and Quick Partners.
"That has been a big driver of Amazon's stock this year.
The core marketplace business remains robust and impressive, but it's been less of a driving force this year than in prior years."
AWS is a massive cloud-computing platform that operates across 11 geographical regions from around the globe.
The business offers dozens of different products and services, ranging from virtual servers and archive storage to data transport and private cloud networking.
It's one of three main business segments at Amazon.
The others are the main e-commerce site and Amazon Prime, a membership program that gives customers access to streaming video, music, e-books, free shipping and other deals and services.
While all its businesses continue to thrive, Amazon is rapidly expanding its AWS products and services.
In October, it launched AWS IoT, a new cloud computing service that lets customers build cloud-based apps for Web-connected devices.
The division now leads the cloud infrastructure market that includes the likes ofMicrosoft ( MSFT ),Salesforce.com ( CRM ),Alphabet 's ( GOOGL ) Google andVMware ( VMW ).
During the third quarter, Amazon Web Services held a 36.9% share of the cloud infrastructure market, according to a report from Goldman Sachs.
Microsoft ranked a distant second with an 8.7% market share while Salesforce.com followed with 4.7%.
Amazon established that lead through an aggressive growth plan that began a few years analyst Moran said in an interview.
"They built data centers throughout the country," he said.
"As they grew in size they cut pricing to gain market share."
The price cuts went into effect in April 2014 and hindered revenue growth at AWS, Moran says.
But with demand rising for cloud products and services, the pricing environment is much better now than it was last year.
"Over the last year we've seen a dramatic rise in companies outsourcing their computing needs to the cloud, and specifically to Amazon Web Services," Moran said.
"At the same time, pricing has become more stable.
Over the last few quarters Amazon Web Services has gone from 50% year-over-year growth to 80% growth."
RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney noted in a report that during the third quarter the AWS segment posted profit of $521 million on revenue of $2.08 billion.
The revenue figure was up 78% from the prior year.
He expects similar growth over the next two quarters as AWS benefits from better prices and higher demand for cloud services.
"The higher-margin revenue (from Web services) will continue to positively affect total company margins," Mahaney noted.
Amazon posted a better-than-expected operating margin of 3.9% during the third quarter -- the highest Q3 margin in five years, Mahaney said.
Earnings for the quarter came in at 17 cents a share.
That reversed a 95-cent per-share loss from the previous year and came in well ahead of forecasts for a 13-cent shortfall.
Revenue climbed 23% to $25.4 billion, topping views of $24.9 billion.
Revenue in the North America segment grew 28% year-over-year to $15 billion.
That compares with a 7% rise to $8.3 billion in the international segment.
Excluding a $1.3 billion year-over-year unfavorable foreign exchange impact, international revenue growth was 24%.

On a conference call with analysts, Amazon Chief Financial Officer Brian Olsavsky said international growth is being driven by the Amazon Prime business, including a wider selection of Prime products and services.
"It's essentially the same playbook at the U.S. -- the additional Prime features," he said.
"We like the trends in international, and they mirror many of the same things we see in North America."
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see Amazon's fourth-quarter earnings more than tripling to $1.61 a share on the expectation of a strong holiday season.
JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth expects domestic online sales growth of 13% this holiday season for all online retailers, including Amazon andEbay (EBAY).
That's off a tough comparison to the prior year, when sales rose 16%.
Anmuth says the sector should benefit from rising incomes in the U.S., lower gas prices, declining unemployment and an extra shopping day between Thanksgiving and Christmas.
"We believe Amazon is well-positioned to continue its market share gains," Anmuth noted in a Nov. 23 report.
Moran expects Amazon to log $22 billion in North American online sales during the fourth quarter, up from $17 billion the prior year.
"Amazon.com has seen electronics sales accelerate the last few quarters," he said.
"With more shifting of consumer spending patterns to online sales, Amazon will post a very strong Q4 holiday performance."
All of these positive trends have not gone unnoticed on Wall Street.
Amazon's stock price set a new high of 682.77 on Nov. 23 and still trades near there.
Shares started the year around 300.
Amazon has an IBD Composite Rating of 97 out of a possible 99.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
